title: Visualizations
text:
In the line plot showing global average forest area percentage, we can see a sharp decrease over time. This could be due to an increase of global warming, urbanization, or deforestation over time.




Source: Forests.ipynb






This bar plot shows the 10 countries that had the highest forest area percent in the year 2022. Suriname had the highest percent of forest area in 2022.











This bar plot shows the 10 countries that had the lowest forest area percentage in the year 2022. We can see Monaco had the lowest forest area.











Here, we visualize the average forest area by region, specifically in the year of 2022. This follows the summary statistic stated before, where the East Asia & Pacific region had the highest average forest area over all years, and the Middle East & North Africa had the lowest.











This bar plot shows the average forest area by income group, specifically in the year 2022. It is evident that the upper middle income group had the highest forest area during this year, while low income countries had the lowest. This could be due to lack of resources in low income countries, as well as infrastructure.








        
        
In this interactive map, we can see the forest area percentages in each country over time.

from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error, r2_score

df = merged_df.copy()
df = pd.get_dummies(df, columns=['Region', 'IncomeGroup'], drop_first=True)

x = df.drop(columns=['Country Name', 'Country Code', 'Forest Area (% of land area)'])   # x is year, region, incomegroup
y = df['Forest Area (% of land area)']       # outcome

x_train, x_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(x, y, test_size=0.3, random_state=42)

lmod = LinearRegression().fit(x_train, y_train)

y_pred = lmod.predict(x_test)

mse = mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred)
r2 = r2_score(y_test, y_pred)
print("MSE: ", mse)
print("R^2: ", r2)

title: MSDS597 Data Wrangling: Final Project Summary
text:
Data
The dataset we utilized in this project is from the World Bank Group. It contains data about the Forest area around the world (by % of land area). Forest area is considered as land under natural or planted stands of trees of at least 5 meters. The World Bank Group attains this forest area information from the Food and Agriculture Organization, in which they collect the data in intervals of 5-10 years. The formats of the Forest data came in 3 forms: CSV file, Excel file, and XML file. It contained the country names, country codes, and the percent of land area that was occupied by forests from years 1960 to 2023. It also had a separate metadata CSV file that contained data for each country including the region it was located in and income group. We retrieved the data from the World Bank data website.


Data Cleaning
Since this dataset was large, we resized it to transform the raw data into tidy tubular data. We began by removing unneeded columns (Indicator Name, Indicator Code) and turned the wide dataframe into a long dataframe to have Year as a column. We also dropped NaN values of forest area for years 1960 to 1989, since they were missing. We then merged the metadata with the long dataframe based on Country Code to add Income Group and Region columns. Some rows in Country Name had NaN values in Region and Income Group, because there were region names in the Country Name column. To resolve this issue, we dropped these values to keep only countries in our tidy data. We verified our cleaned dataframe using the assert statement to check that there were no NaN values or duplicates. The final cleaned dataframe can be found in Forests.ipynb.


Summary Statistics
Summary statistics we found important:

Summary statistics of global forest area per year: The year 1991 recorded the highest average forest area and 2021 had the lowest average forest area. The decline of forest percentage over time suggests the increase of deforestation and land use changes, like urbanization.
Summary statistics of forest area by country: Suriname had the highest average forest area over the 32 years and Gibraltar had the lowest average forest area over all.
Average forest area by Region: The East Asia & Pacific region had the highest average forest area across all years, approximately 49.04%. In contrast, the Middle East & North Africa region had the lowest average forest area over all years of about 2.83%. This could be due to several factors, including differences in climate, geography, and land use. The East Asia and Pacific region includes several countries with large forested areas. The Middle East and North Africa region has areas with dry climates and limited rainfall that would naturally restrict the growth of forests.
Average forest area by Income Group: The upper middle income group countries had the highest average forest area (36.37%), while the low income group countries had the lowest average forest area (24.74%) overall. This disparity may be due to the limited resources and infrastructure in low income countries.



Regression
We also wanted to examine how well just three parameters could predict forest area. By using a linear regressioin model, we were able to predict Forest Area (% of land area) using parameters Year, Region, and Income Group. We trained the model with 70% of the data, and analyzed the performance using the remaining 30% of data. We found to have a very high MSE of 455.34 and a low \(R^2\) of 0.26, meaning that only 26% of the variance in the outcome variable was explained in the predictors. Therefore, this model with just the three parameters performed poorly.
Visualizations can be found in the Visualizations tab.
The code for everything above can be found in Forests.ipynb
